infopoints.info:
When we get older our hair thins and goes grey. Why?

Special cells called melanocytes found in the hair follicle produce hair colour by incorporating pigment into the growing hair fibres.

At the end of each hair cycle, some pigment-producing melanocytes become damaged and die.

When the reservoir of melanocytes is exhausted, pigment production stops and the hair turns grey.

When we get older our skin wrinkles, becomes darker, thinner, and develops spots.

Wrinkles begin at a number of places on your face; usually at areas you move the most, like the far corners of your eyes (crow’s feet) and on your forehead, just above the brow.

For many people, the next area of wrinkles is at the sides of the mouth, leaving deep crevices called laugh lines.

When we get older our ears and nose continue to grow and get longer as we age because they are made of cartilage, a flexible connective tissue which continues to grow until we die.

Cartilage also becomes thinner with age, causing the ears stretch down and the tip of the nose lengthens and droops.

In many men, forests of hair sprout from their ears, nose, and back.

Before we die we’ll have shrunk in height by an average of 4.9 cm for women and 2.9 cm for men.

Did someone let the air out of our tires? What’s the reason for this loss in stature?

One big reason is water loss.

Between each vertebra in your back are jelly-like disks that help absorb any shock your backbone receives.

As you get older, the disks lose water and you lose height.

The top layer, the epidermis, thins. After our bodies peak in our 20’s, our epidermis starts to lose cells at a rate of 10% per decade.

Think of the skin’s bottom layer, the dermis, as an elastic band. Every time we smile or frown or make some expression our dermis gets a good workout. Well after decades of being stretched and yanked, the dermis starts to lose its elasticity.

Ultraviolet sunrays can also cause the dermis to loose elasticity. The more unprotected sun someone receives, the more likely they will wrinkle at an earlier age and have deeper wrinkles.
